title: The Jan. 6 case against Trump: He knew he was lying

mainContent.title: The Jan. 6 case against Trump: He knew he was lying
mainContent.description: Thirty-one months later, Donald Trump has been charged over the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, with his unprecedented role in an unprecedented event spelled out in a lengthy indictment. The case amounts to this: Trump knew he was lying about the election. Prosecutors have notes from his VP, Mike Pence.

typeAttributes.deck: Charges detail Trump's behind-the-scenes instructions to his VP Mike Pence and others

mainVisual.title: Trump represents 'greatest threat to American democracy,' former ambassador says
mainVisual.description: Bruce Heyman, the former United States ambassador to Canada, says the indictments against former U.S. president Donald Trump aren't unexpected, but despite the charges, he believes it's still possible for Trump to be re-elected.

typeAttributes.deck: Bruce Heyman, the former United States ambassador to Canada, says the indictments against former U.S. president Donald Trump aren't unexpected, but despite the charges, he believes it's still possible for Trump to be re-elected.

headlineimage.title: The National | 3rd Trump indictment, Meta blocks news, Bear or human?

content.deck: Aug. 1, 2023 | Former U.S. president Donald Trump now faces a third criminal indictment, this time for his efforts to overturn his 2020 election loss. Facebook and Instagram parent company Meta is going ahead with blocking news content on its platforms in Canada. Plus, a bear at a zoo in China standing on its hind legs and waving has some speculating it's a human in a bear suit.
content.description: Aug. 1, 2023 | Former U.S. president Donald Trump now faces a third criminal indictment, this time for his efforts to overturn his 2020 election loss. Facebook and Instagram parent company Meta is going ahead with blocking news content on its platforms in Canada. Plus, a bear at a zoo in China standing on its hind legs and waving has some speculating it's a human in a bear suit.

content.deck: Former U.S. president has now been criminally charged for the 3rd time in 4 months
content.description: Donald Trump on Tuesday was hit with criminal charges for a third time in four months  this time arising from efforts to overturn his 2020 U.S. election defeat  as he campaigns to regain the presidency next year.

intlinks.description: Former U.S. president Donald Trump said Tuesday he has received a letter informing him that he is a target of the Justice Department's investigation into efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election, an indication he could soon be charged by prosecutors.

intlinks.description: Former U.S. president Donald Trump pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to 37 federal criminal charges that he unlawfully kept national-security documents when he left office and lied to officials who sought to recover them.

content.deck: Former U.S. president and 2024 Republican candidate indicted 3 times since April, and other cases loom
content.description: Donald Trump is defiant in the face of Espionage Act charges centred on mishandling documents while ex-president. But he now faces 40 charges overall in a case set to go to trial in March 2024, as well as ongoing probes elsewhere.

intlinks.description: Donald Trump's federal indictment includes charges under the Espionage Act, according to one of his former lawyers. Learn more about the wartime law that has been used to prosecute spies and whistleblowers, and has often been a source of controversy.
intlinks.title: Trump's federal indictment: What is the Espionage Act?
intlinks.shareheadline: What is the Espionage Act?

intlinks.description: As the fallout from the removal of potentially classified documents from Donald Trump's Florida home plays out, here's a look at some recent cases where individuals in and connected to the U.S. government have been convicted for possessing or passing on classified material.
intlinks.title: Trump may be a special case, but others have paid for mishandling classified material
intlinks.shareheadline: Trump may be a special case, but others have paid for mishandling classified material

intlinks.description: The former president faces a frightful prospect: potentially decades in prison, a de-facto life sentence for a 77-year-old man accused of illegally hoarding, showing, and hiding top-secret documents. There are, however, several ways Trump could walk free.
intlinks.title: Here are 4 ways Trump could walk free
intlinks.shareheadline: Trump is facing his toughest legal fight yet. Here are 4 ways he could walk free

content.deck: No consensus on whether hearings helped prosecution chances, but testimony made for memorable sound bites
content.description: They'll be back. That's what members of the House select committee investigating former U.S. president Donald Trump's effort to overturn the 2020 election promised at the conclusion of their last public hearing of the summer. We look at what legal and political analysts say were some of the most significant moments so far.

headlinemedia.deck: WASHINGTON, DC - JULY 21: Representative Liz Cheney, a Republican from Wyoming, center, speaks during a hearing of the Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the US Capitol on July 21, 2022 in Washington, DC. The bipartisan committee, which has been gathering evidence on the January 6 attack at the U.S. Capitol, is presenting its findings in a series of televised hearings. On January 6, 2021, supporters of former President Donald Trump attacked the U.S. Capitol Building during an attempt to disrupt a congressional vote to confirm the electoral college win for President Joe Biden.  (Photo by Al Drago-Pool/Getty Images)
headlinemedia.description: WASHINGTON, DC - JULY 21: Representative Liz Cheney, a Republican from Wyoming, center, speaks during a hearing of the Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the US Capitol on July 21, 2022 in Washington, DC. The bipartisan committee, which has been gathering evidence on the January 6 attack at the U.S. Capitol, is presenting its findings in a series of televised hearings. On January 6, 2021, supporters of former President Donald Trump attacked the U.S. Capitol Building during an attempt to disrupt a congressional vote to confirm the electoral college win for President Joe Biden.  (Photo by Al Drago-Pool/Getty Images)

bio.name: Kazi Stastna
bio.biography: Kazi Stastna is a senior producer with CBCNews.ca. She has worked as a features writer and copy editor with CBC's digital news team for over a decade. Prior to that, she was at the Montreal Gazette and worked as a reporter and editor in Germany and the Czech Republic.

title: More residents of Osoyoos, B.C., heading home as nearby wildfire grows away from town

mainContent.title: More residents of Osoyoos, B.C., heading home as nearby wildfire grows away from town
mainContent.description: More residents of Osoyoos, B.C., and the surrounding area are being allowed to return home after being forced out by a fast-moving wildfire that spread from neighbouring Washington state over the weekend.

typeAttributes.deck: More than 1,000 residents of town on Canada-U.S. border remain on evacuation alert

mainVisual.title: CANADA-WILDFIRES/
mainVisual.description: Locals gather to watch firefighting efforts amid heavy smoke from the Eagle Bluff wildfire after it crossed the Canada-U.S. border from the state of Washington and prompted evacuation orders in Osoyoos, British Columbia, Canada, July 30, 2023.
mainVisual.altText: Two men watch as a wildfire on the other side of a large hill sends plumes of smoke into the air.

content.deck: 'I will do what I do best, which is cook lots of meals and feed lots of people'
content.description: Two small business owners have mobilized a huge operation to make sure the men and women on the front lines of the Eagle Bluff wildfire have three solid meals a day while they do battle with the elements.

headlinemedia.deck: Melissa Genberg, left, and Sara Van Der Hoeven, right, are leading efforts in Osoyoos, B.C., to feed hundreds of wildfire fighters stationed in the Okanagan community by collecting donations, fundraising, cooking and serving three meals a day.
headlinemedia.alt: Two women pose with their heads together, photographed from the neck up in a 'selfie' style photo. The woman on the left has a big smile, two dark braids and is wearing a black hat that says O-Town in yellow font. To her right is a blond woman wearing black-framed glasses and also smiling. Behind them are a barbeque and a line of firefighters forming to get a meal.
headlinemedia.description: Melissa Genberg, left, and Sara Van Der Hoeven, right, are leading efforts in Osoyoos, B.C., to feed hundreds of wildfire fighters stationed in the Okanagan community by collecting donations, fundraising, cooking and serving three meals a day.
headlinemedia.title: osoyoos volunteers
headlinemedia.headline: osoyoos volunteers

intlinks.description: Summer afternoon hailstorms are a part of life in Calgary. Its why a team of researchers have installed a network of sophisticated weather stations across the city to study the storms that regularly pummel buildings and cars  sometimes causing tremendous damage.

content.deck: About 700 properties in southern B.C. town had to be evacuated because of a wildfire
content.description: Dave McGlynn and Sherry Zarowny rushed to get their horses to safety on Saturday night after McGlynn saw a plume of smoke on the horizon. Their property, along with about 700 others in Osoyoos, B.C., had to be evacuated because of a wildfire that crossed over from the United States.

headlinemedia.deck: Dave McGlynn and Sherry Zarowny were able to load up their horses into trailers and get them out of harms way on Saturday night.
headlinemedia.alt: The back of a truck with horse riding equipment, and two horse trailers attached to trucks.
headlinemedia.description: Dave McGlynn and Sherry Zarowny were able to load up their horses into trailers and get them out of harms way on Saturday night.
headlinemedia.title: Horses Osoyoos
headlinemedia.headline: Horses Osoyoos

secondary.localHeadline: PHOTOS | Eagle Bluff wildfire threatens B.C. community

item.title: Wildfire crosses U.S. border, threatens B.C. community of Osoyoos
item.description: The Eagle Bluff wildfire forced hundreds of residents in and around the southern Interior community to evacuate on Saturday.

images.localDescription: Water bombers and other firefighting aircraft flew over Osoyoos, B.C., on Sunday as crews fought an out-of-control wildfire that crossed into Canada from Washington State on Sunday. The fire had forced the evacuation of more than 700 properties.
Children sat on the roof of a truck to watch firefighting efforts as wildfire smoke turned the sky around Osoyoos, B.C., an eerie shade of orange on Sunday.
A central area of Osoyoos is pictured on Sunday. The community's population swells in the summer as visitors from B.C. and Alberta seek out the area's hot weather, warm lake and winery scene.
The wildfire is seen burning in the hills above town on Sunday. The fire started in Washington state, but crossed the Canada-U.S. border on Saturday.
An air tanker drops fire retardant on the fire on Sunday. The B.C. Wildfire Service said crews prioritized the eastern edge of the fire through the day.
A water bomber flies over a home in Osoyoos on Sunday.
A long exposure image shows the Eagle Bluff Wildfire near Osoyoos Lake on Sunday.
The Eagle Bluff Wildfire burns on the Canada-U.S. border after it crossed from near Oroville, Wash.
A small town of around 5,000 near the U.S. border, Osoyoos's lake access, wineries and golf courses make it a tourist destination.
Residents of more than 700 properties were ordered to evacuate and more than 2,000 properties were placed on evacuation alert due to the Eagle Bluff Wildfire.
The fire, which crossed the border, is the most concerning fire to pop up in B.C. in recent days.

typeAttributes.deck: More than 1,000 residents of town on Canada-U.S. border remain on evacuation alert

title: Archaeologists identify Iron Age remains as those of a female warrior
description: Remains found in an Iron Age burial chamber on the Isles of Scilly belonged to a female warrior, according to the authors of a new study that challenges long-held assumptions about the historical role of women in warfare.

typeAttributes.deck: New technique that identifies sex using tooth enamel is changing historical narratives

title: Saying 'I love you' with 1.2 million sunflowers
description: Kansas farmer Lee Wilson didn't know what to get his wife Renee for their 50th wedding anniversary, until inspiration struck. She loved sunflowers, so he decided to turn 80 acres into an unending field of yellow, growing 1.2 million blooms to mark their celebratory milestone together.

typeAttributes.deck: Kansas farmer Lee Wilson didn't know what to get his wife Renee for their 50th wedding anniversary, until inspiration struck. title: Lizzo sued by former dancers who allege sexual harassment, hostile work environment
description: A civil lawsuit filed Tuesday in Los Angeles County Superior Court claims Lizzo pressured dancers to engage with nude performers at a club in Amsterdam and shamed one of them for her weight gain before firing her.

primary.localheadline: Minimum wage couldn't get you a 1-bedroom unit years ago. It's even worse now

content.deck: High rents in major cities mean those making minimum wage are at risk of becoming homeless, report suggests
content.description: A new report released Tuesday by the Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives found that while minimum wages have risen since 2018, they haven't increased as fast as rental rates. Researchers say this not only leaves workers spending too much on rent, but ultimately puts minimum wage workers at risk of becoming homeless.

headlinemedia.deck: Sylvana Orellana, 23, is a Toronto renter. She says she's struggling to pay rent, provide for herself and her son, and cover the rest of her daily expenses while earning minimum wage, even with support from friends and family.
headlinemedia.alt: A woman looks at the camera for a photo.
headlinemedia.description: Sylvana Orellana, 23, is a Toronto renter. She says she's struggling to pay rent, provide for herself and her son, and cover the rest of her daily expenses while earning minimum wage, even with support from friends and family.

content.deck: Collaborative Home Ownership site offers shared partnership 'matchmaking' and events, says Vancouver Realtor
content.description: Some Lower Mainland residents are turning to unorthodox methods in the battle against unaffordable housing prices, choosing, in some cases, to pool money with strangers in order to buy a home.

headlinemedia.deck: Vancouver Realtor Noam Dolgin is helping Lower Mainland residents find partners to purchase homes. Legal advocates warn these new types of partnerships are more risky than they seem.
headlinemedia.alt: A blue and grey brick home has white pillars and stairs leading up to the door. In front of the house is a sign for Realtor Noam Dolgin with a plaque on top reading, 'Share this home.'
headlinemedia.description: Vancouver Realtor Noam Dolgin is helping Lower Mainland residents find partners to purchase homes. Legal advocates warn these new types of partnerships are more risky than they seem.

bio.biography: Arrthy Thayaparan is an associate producer at CBC Vancouver. She's interested in health, environment, and community stories. You can contact her at arrthy.thayaparan@cbc.ca.

intlinks.description: Top stories from British Columbia
intlinks.title: Top stories from British Columbia
intlinks.shareheadline: Top stories from British Columbia

intlinks.description: A Fort Nelson, B.C., man found himself the unexpected companion of a moose calf, who he says willingly hopped into the passenger seat of his truck to escape the jaws of a waiting black bear.
intlinks.title: B.C. man fired from job after saving moose calf on the highway
intlinks.shareheadline: B.C. man fired from job after saving moose calf on the highway

intlinks.description: Grieving parents who lost their nine-year-old boy last week say their son died after a severe asthma attack made worse by wildfire smoke engulfing parts of British Columbia.
intlinks.title: Boy, 9, died of asthma attack made worse by wildfire smoke, parents say
intlinks.shareheadline: Boy, 9, died of asthma attack made worse by wildfire smoke, parents say

intlinks.description: A working group comprised of members of Public Safety Canada, the Canadian Armed Forces and British Columbia emergency management and wildfire officials are set to meet today as several hundred blazes burn across the province.
intlinks.title: Military begins deployment, highway to Bella Coola closed as hundreds of wildfires burn across B.C.
intlinks.shareheadline: Military begins deployment, highway to Bella Coola closed as hundreds of wildfires burn across B.C.

title: Alberta halting pursuit of provincial police force
description: The Alberta government is no longer formally pursuing its plan to dump the RCMP in favour of a new provincial police force.

typeAttributes.deck: No mention of proposal in latest justice mandate letter

title: Former CAO accused of faking cyberattack to cover theft of $500K from Manitoba municipality
description: A former chief administrative officer stole more than half a million dollars from a western Manitoba municipality's bank account, and then tried to cover it up by fabricating a story about a cyberattack and altering documents, a lawsuit filed last month alleges.

typeAttributes.deck: Lawsuit alleges former chief administrative officer of Gilbert Plains modified bank statements, reports
